etymologies: late 16th century (as a verb): frequentative of dialect stut, of Germanic origin; related to German stossen ‘strike against’

definitions: talk with continued involuntary repetition of sounds, especially initial consonants

examples.text: the child was stuttering in fright

shortDefinitions: talk with continued involuntary repetition of sounds

definitions: utter with involuntary repetition of sounds

examples.text: he shyly stuttered out an invitation to the movies

shortDefinitions: say something with difficulty, repeating initial consonants of words

definitions: (of a machine or gun) produce a series of short, sharp sounds

examples.text: she flinched as a machine gun stuttered nearby

shortDefinitions: produce series of short, sharp sounds

definitions: progress in a hesitant or irregular way

examples.text: the country still has problems, not least that its economy is stuttering and unemployment is high

definitions: a tendency to stutter while speaking

examples.text: “She's p-perfectly j-justified,” he said with his intermittent stutter

definitions: a series of short, sharp sounds produced by a machine or gun

examples.text: a machine gun shattered the quiet with its explosive stutter

shortDefinitions: series of short, sharp sounds produced by machine or gun
